ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Advanced topics in phonetics related to articulation, acoustics, and DFT/speech perception
Broad overview of articulation, acoustics, and perception, plus familiarity with Matlab (not writing code but running it).
Learned much more in the three areas of Articulation, Acoustics, and Perception.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was very interesting, and I think could have been improved with more conversation about the background of some of the theories discussed!

Strengths: Jason is a really approachable professor and passionate about phonetics; the workload is very reasonable and hard work pays off; class is super well organized. Weaknesses: lectures can get a bit dry, the final paper is hard.

Strengths: Great professor. Interesting, mostly self-contained units.
Weaknesses: Not necessarily a weakness, but it may be helpful to have taken at least a little bit of high school physics before this course. There was more math involved than the QR credit I took at the same time (which involved very little math)
Strengths: Very well organized presentations and a great continuation of Phonetics 1. The MATLAB exercises were not difficult to work through and demonstrated interesting phonetic concepts.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes I would recommend this to Linguistics (phonology/phonetics), Cognitive Science, or Physics students. Non-linguistics majors seemed to still really enjoy the class

Yes! Know that it's split into 3 units that each take up a third of the class (articulation, acoustics, and perception), so if you're only interested in one of them you might be less engaged during 2/3 of the semester. I really appreciated the leminar format where most classes were a lecture because it felt like concrete content was being taught. Jason is a really approachable professor and the workload is very reasonable, so if the topic sounds interesting to you, you will enjoy the class.
Yes! Dr. Shaw is passionate about his subject, and you will walk away knowing a fair bit about each topic (speech articulation, acoustics, and speech perception).

Yes, it is a fantastic phonetics II class! This was the first time it was ever taught and it went incredibly smoothly. You will learn a lot in articulation, acoustics, and perception. Perception particularly was a great unit because it was touched on the least in Phonetics I. Jason does not re-explain anything from phonetics 1 unless you ask (he is happy to though), so if you did not take phonetics 1 you might expect to spend some time looking up various terms like reminding yourself what a lateral alveolar approximant is for example.
